reviews.name: Hung Cao
reviews.content: My teacher gave me this book when I left for America and I'm honestly surprised and so in love with it. This story at its core is a coming of age story, we follow Chuong, a city boy who has to spend the summer in the countryside of Vietnam with his aunt and cousins. Over the course of this book, the protagonist runs into some misfits, have some small adventures, and learn some important life lessons, there is an element of romance as well. Now for me, the book hits me really hard because I can relate so much to it, it reminded of my life before I had to move to America, at the end of the book I almost teared up because it gave me so much nostalgia and when I closed it I was just left with an empty feeling. Overall, I recommend it. Now I'm going to go into more details so spoilers I guess. As much as I love the book I don't really like Chuong, from the start of the book to halfway through I didn't really like him, he can sometimes be stupid, immature, and bratty but it's a coming of age story so at the end you do see him acting more mature. It's not only a coming of age story but also a story about young love, while Chuong is enjoying his summer he met a soft-spoken girl named Them, Chuong, of course, fell for her but it seems very one-sided. Because of this romance element that also contributed to the feeling of emptiness and sorrow at the end of the book for me. Them is engaged to someone else already, this revelation hit Chuong like a truck, but instead of acting selfish or just being childish he just put on a smile, gave her a goodbye gift and go back to the busy city. This just made my heart sank, I was speechless, so I just put the book down and just sat for a while as so many emotions were rushing through me. I truly felt empty.

reviews.name: HoÃ ng  Thu Thuá»·
reviews.content: I am not a fan of NNA. Personally, his storyline usually doesn't touch my feeling, it 's boring and safe. But I highly appreciate his writing style, he exclusively creates a combination of bitness and sweetness, all-ages story. Maybe, I am a picky person who tries hard to find something more profound. The senses appearing through his language description such as Vietnam village, humans, and traditional culture are very beautiful and real as much as make us feel like we daily meet it somewhere. "Mat biec" is not an exception. The story is about an unresponded-love, the boy meets a girl with "dreamy eyes" since their childhood. And he still keeps this untold-love inside, after 20 years later, and witnesses the girl becomes a woman and a single mom. Even though I just have read it because of the incoming movie. The trailer and soundtracks hit my feeling so harsh. One more time, I fall in love with his writing style, not the contents.

reviews.name: GlassyPizzaFingers
reviews.content: I read this book in Vietnamese about five or six years back, when I first came to the U.S. I remember bringing this book from Vietnam as a gift from my cousin, whom I refer to as sister. This is a very lovely book from Nguyá»…n Nháº­t Ãnh; he captures the easy-going, and exciting life of many Vietnamese children very well, and of course, this book was not written for children, rather, it was for adults who want a ticket back to their childhoods, a trip down the memory lane. This book serves that purpose very well; it is fast-paced, easy to read, lighthearted. The tone is distinctly that of the South, very down-to-earth, full-of-live, immensely innocent, but unfortunately, all of this, including the quirkiness, got lost during translation. I don't get the same fondness feeling when I read the English the version. But that doesn't mean it is not good, people!
